title: Fix entry list scroll containment for keyboard navigation
description:
## Summary

When navigating entries with j/k keyboard shortcuts, the entire page scrolls instead of just the entry list. This causes the entry content header (right pane) to scroll out of view, breaking the reading experience.

## Expected Behavior

- Entry list should be height-constrained to the viewport
- j/k navigation should scroll only within the entry list pane
- Entry content header should always remain visible

## Current Behavior

- The `scrollIntoView({ block: "nearest" })` call in EntryList triggers page-level scrolling
- User loses sight of the article title/header when navigating through entries

## Root Cause Analysis

The layout structure in `application.tsx:354-402`:
- Root: `height: 100vh`, `overflow: hidden`
- EntryList container: `width: 320px`, `height: 100%`

The EntryList component (`EntryList.tsx:48-96`):
- Outer div: `h-full flex flex-col`
- Header: `h-12 shrink-0`
- ScrollArea: `flex-1`

The ScrollArea viewport (`scroll-area.tsx:17-21`):
- Has `size-full` (100% width/height)
- But may not be properly constrained by flex parent

## Potential Fix

The Radix ScrollArea needs explicit height containment. Options:

### Option A: Add overflow containment
```tsx
// In EntryList.tsx, wrap ScrollArea parent
<div className="flex-1 min-h-0 overflow-hidden">
  <ScrollArea className="h-full">
```

The `min-h-0` is critical - flex items default to `min-height: auto` which prevents shrinking below content size.

### Option B: Use CSS overflow directly
```tsx
// Replace ScrollArea with native scroll
<div className="flex-1 overflow-y-auto min-h-0">
```

### Option C: Fix ScrollArea component
```tsx
// In scroll-area.tsx, add overflow: hidden to Root
<ScrollAreaPrimitive.Root
  className={cn("relative overflow-hidden", className)}
```

## Files to Modify

- `app/javascript/components/EntryList.tsx` - Add `min-h-0` to flex container
- Possibly `app/javascript/components/ui/scroll-area.tsx` - Ensure proper containment

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] j/k navigation scrolls only the entry list, not the page
- [ ] Entry content header remains visible during navigation
- [ ] Scrollbar appears on entry list when entries exceed viewport
- [ ] Mouse wheel scrolling still works within entry list
close_reason: Fixed scroll containment by adding overflow-hidden to ScrollArea root and min-h-0 to flex containers. j/k navigation now scrolls only within entry list.

title: Deep linking and URL routing system
description:
## Summary

Implement URL-based routing and deep linking to enable shareable links, browser history support, and digest email integration.

## Deep Link Types

### a) Link to a feed
```
/feeds/:id
/categories/:id
/views/fresh
/views/starred
/views/all
```

### b) Link to a specific item
```
/entries/:id
```
Opens the app with that entry selected/focused in the content pane.

### c) Link to a set of items, focused on one
```
/digest/:date          â€” Articles from a specific digest (by date)
/digest/:uuid          â€” Custom curated set of articles (shareable collection)
/entries?ids=1,2,3&focus=2
```

The UUID approach enables:
- Building a custom set of items to share
- "Share this collection" feature
- Digest emails with stable links
- Saved searches or smart folders (future)

## Open Questions

1. **URL structure**: Query params vs path segments?
   - `/entries/123` vs `/entries?id=123`
   - `/digest/2025-01-15` vs `/digest?date=2025-01-15`

2. **Collection persistence**: Where do custom collections live?
   - Database table: `collections(uuid, user_id, entry_ids[], created_at)`
   - Or ephemeral with signed/encoded IDs in URL?

3. **Auth for shared links**: 
   - Public links (no auth required)?
   - Signed URLs with expiry?
   - Login required, then redirect?

4. **State sync complexity**:
   - What state goes in URL vs stays local?
   - Sort order? Filters? Scroll position?

5. **Router choice**:
   - React Router?
   - TanStack Router?
   - Custom with History API?
   - Rails-driven (turbo frames)?

## Implementation Layers

### Layer 1: Basic routing (prerequisite for all)
- URL â†” app state sync
- Browser back/forward
- `/feeds/:id`, `/entries/:id`, `/views/:name`

### Layer 2: Shareable entry links
- `/entries/:id` works without auth (public read?)
- Or requires auth, then redirects

### Layer 3: Collection/digest links
- Database model for collections
- `/digest/:uuid` resolves to entry set
- UI for "Share these articles"

## Depends On

- Foundational for: ttrb-weo (email digests), ttrb-i72 (multi-select share)

## Blocked

Needs design discussion before implementation:
- [ ] Decide URL structure conventions
- [ ] Decide on collection persistence model
- [ ] Decide auth model for shared links
- [ ] Choose routing library

description:
## Summary

In the feed organizer, the dragged element visual is offset downward from the actual cursor position. This misalignment makes it impossible to drop feeds onto the first folder/category.

## Current Behavior

- When dragging a feed, the drag preview/ghost appears lower than the cursor
- Drop zone detection seems to use cursor position, but visual is offset
- Cannot drop on the first folder because the visual offset puts the "apparent" drop position below it
- Lower folders work because there's room for the offset

## Expected Behavior

- Dragged element should track directly with cursor
- Or drop zones should account for the offset
- All folders should be reachable as drop targets, including the first one

## Likely Cause

This is a common issue with dnd-kit when:
- Transform offset not calculated correctly
- Scroll position not accounted for
- Header/toolbar height throwing off calculations
- `useSortable` transform not properly applied

## Possible Fixes

1. Check dnd-kit `activatorEvent` and ensure offset is calculated from grab point
2. Use `modifiers` to adjust drag overlay position
3. Verify no CSS transforms on parent containers affecting coordinates
4. Check if scroll containers are affecting position calculation

```tsx
// Example modifier to fix offset
import { restrictToVerticalAxis, restrictToWindowEdges } from '@dnd-kit/modifiers'

<DndContext modifiers={[restrictToVerticalAxis]}>
```

## Files to Check

- `app/javascript/components/FeedOrganizer.tsx` - DndContext and useSortable usage
- Check for any CSS transforms on ancestor elements

## Reproduction Steps

1. Open Settings â†’ Feeds (organizer)
2. Drag any feed
3. Notice the dragged element appears lower than cursor
4. Try to drop on the first category - fails because offset

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Dragged element aligns with cursor position
- [ ] Can drop on all folders including the first one
- [ ] Smooth drag experience without visual jumping

description:
## Summary

Add multi-select capability to the entry list using the `x` key, enabling bulk actions on selected entries.

## Concept

Use `x` key in conjunction with j/k navigation to select/deselect entries:
- **x**: Toggle selection on current entry
- **j/k**: Navigate (selection persists)
- **Shift+x** or **X**: Select range (from last selected to current)
- **Escape**: Clear all selections

## Potential Bulk Actions

Once multiple entries are selected:
- **s**: Star/unstar all selected
- **m**: Mark all selected read/unread
- **d**: Delete all selected (with confirmation)
- **Share as digest**: Export selected entries as a formatted digest (email, markdown, etc.)
- **Add label**: Apply a label to all selected
- **Move to category**: Bulk categorization

## UX Considerations

### Visual Feedback
- Selected entries need distinct visual treatment (checkbox? highlight? badge?)
- Selection count indicator in header
- Clear indication of "selection mode" vs "focus mode"

### Interaction Model Options

**Option A: Gmail-style (persistent selection)**
- x toggles selection, stays on current item
- Selection persists across navigation
- Actions apply to selection if any, otherwise current item

**Option B: Vim visual mode**
- v enters "visual/select mode"
- j/k extends selection
- Action or Escape exits mode

**Option C: Shift-based (simpler)**
- Shift+j/k extends selection from current
- No explicit x key, just shift modifiers

## Open Questions

1. Should selection persist when changing feeds/views?
2. How does selection interact with "mark all read" (existing feature)?
3. Should there be a "select all" shortcut?
4. What's the visual design for selected items?
5. How does this work with virtual scrolling (if implemented later)?
6. Share as digest - what formats? Email? Clipboard? Export file?

## Blocked

This issue is blocked pending UX design discussion. Need to:
- [ ] Decide on interaction model (Option A/B/C or hybrid)
- [ ] Design visual treatment for selected state
- [ ] Define complete list of bulk actions to support
- [ ] Consider mobile/touch implications

title: Configurable accent color system
description:
## Overview
Implement a user-configurable accent color system that derives all theme colors from a single primary hue selection.

## Requirements

### Color Derivation (must be done in code, NOT hardcoded CSS)
1. User selects a primary accent hue (0-360) in Settings
2. JavaScript utility derives:
   - **Secondary color**: Complement of primary (hue + 180, wrapped at 360)
   - **Primary-light**: Higher lightness, slightly reduced saturation
   - **Primary-dark**: Lower lightness
   - **Secondary-light/dark**: Same pattern for secondary

### CSS Variables to Set Dynamically
The utility must set these CSS custom properties on document.documentElement:
- --color-accent-primary
- --color-accent-primary-light
- --color-accent-primary-dark
- --color-accent-secondary
- --color-accent-secondary-light
- --color-accent-secondary-dark

### UI Usage
- Primary: Feed selection highlight in sidebar
- Primary-light: Folder highlight when a child feed is selected
- Secondary: Star icon, unread indicator icon

### Settings Integration
- Add hue picker to Settings dialog
- Store preference in UserPreference (pref_name: 'accent_hue')
- Load and apply on app initialization

## Technical Notes
- Create lib/accentColors.ts with generateAccentColors(hue) and applyAccentColors(hue)
- Initialize colors in application.tsx on mount
- Default hue: 210 (blue) if no preference set

title: Set up Guard for Rails auto-testing
description:
## Summary

Set up Guard with guard-minitest for automatic test running on file changes. This improves developer experience by providing instant feedback during development.

## Current State

- Rails 8.1.1 with Minitest (default test framework)
- No test directory exists yet
- No Guardfile configured

## Implementation Steps

### 1. Add gems to Gemfile (development group)

```ruby
group :development do
  gem "guard"
  gem "guard-minitest"
end
```

Run `bundle install`.

### 2. Initialize Guard

```bash
bundle exec guard init minitest
```

This generates a default Guardfile.

### 3. Configure Guardfile

Customize watch patterns for the app structure:

```ruby
guard :minitest, spring: false, all_on_start: false do
  watch(%r{^test/(.*)_test\.rb$})
  watch(%r{^lib/(.*/)?([^/]+)\.rb$})     { |m| "test/lib/#{m[1]}#{m[2]}_test.rb" }
  watch(%r{^test/test_helper\.rb$})      { "test" }

  # Rails specific
  watch(%r{^app/models/(.+)\.rb$})       { |m| "test/models/#{m[1]}_test.rb" }
  watch(%r{^app/controllers/(.+)\.rb$})  { |m| "test/controllers/#{m[1]}_test.rb" }
  watch(%r{^app/services/(.+)\.rb$})     { |m| "test/services/#{m[1]}_test.rb" }
  watch(%r{^app/jobs/(.+)\.rb$})         { |m| "test/jobs/#{m[1]}_test.rb" }
  watch(%r{^app/mailers/(.+)\.rb$})      { |m| "test/mailers/#{m[1]}_test.rb" }
end
```

### 4. Create test directory structure

```bash
mkdir -p test/{models,controllers,services,jobs,mailers,integration,system}
```

Create `test/test_helper.rb`:

```ruby
ENV["RAILS_ENV"] ||= "test"
require_relative "../config/environment"
require "rails/test_help"

class ActiveSupport::TestCase
  # Run tests in parallel with specified workers
  parallelize(workers: :number_of_processors)

  # Setup all fixtures in test/fixtures/*.yml
  fixtures :all
end
```

### 5. Usage

Start Guard in a terminal:

```bash
bundle exec guard
```

Guard will watch for file changes and automatically run corresponding tests.

## Optional Enhancements

- Add `guard-livereload` for browser refresh on asset changes
- Consider `minitest-reporters` for better test output formatting
- Add notification support (terminal-notifier on macOS)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Guard runs on `bundle exec guard`
- [ ] Saving a model file triggers its corresponding test
- [ ] Saving a controller file triggers its corresponding test
- [ ] Saving a service file triggers its corresponding test
- [ ] Test helper exists and works with `bin/rails test`
